content.description: This is a great line with varied climbing. Start on easier juggy terrain to reach a slab corner. Over the corner, one finds a slab with small feet. The hands improve greatly the higher you get until you are again on massive chickenhead jugs. This is long and fun! It is still cleaning up, and there certainly is a bit of lichen, but the key holds are cleaning up.
content.location:
It is just right of

Night Watch

on the South Face of the Watchtower.

content.description: Start up varied blocky terrain to reach a large, right-angling flake halfway up the buttress. Burly climbing on the steep but positive flake leads to exciting moves up the right edge of the upper flatiron.
content.location:
It is right of

Watchmen

on the South face of the Watchtower.

content.description:
Start from the alcove shared with

Watchmen

. Night Watch breaks left up the arete to reach a huge flake (pillar). Pull left onto the pillar to find great crimps leading you to the top of the pillar. The grade here varies based on how one breaks onto the pillar. Completing the roof pull goes around 10c, and using this crack will take this down to 10a/9+.
content.location: This is on Watchtower's South face right above the point where the approach trail reaches the face.

content.description:
This is the gem of the Watchtower. The climbing begins up a short buttress using face holds and the large crack. Layback and crimp to reach the ledge. This low crack needs a combo of power and finesse. From here, work a bit left to get established in the needle's eye. Layback the entire length of this amazing feature to reach the upper arete. Though it may look very challenging from below, there are several surprisingly good holds up high. Work to the apex to clip the chains.

It ascends a very unusual feature with fun sustained climbing. A classic for sure!
content.location: It is on the right end of the East face of the Watchtower across the gully from Workman's West face.

content.description: Pull the tricky roof with poor feet and hard-to-find hands, and slab it out to the top. This route has a bit of lichen to keep the slab interesting. The guidebook calls it 11a, but that felt stout for the roof.
content.location: The North side of the Watchtower has two bolted routes currently - an 11 with a tricky start right and the 9 crack that steps left. This is the fully bolted line on right. Start by either scrambling up from a bushy gully or 4th Classing from a ledge on left, perhaps anchoring from the first bolt.

content.description: Jam, step left by a bolt, and jam. Clip a bolt prior to the shared anchors.
content.protection: Hand-sized gear and perhaps BD #0.75 to #2, double reds. The lower bolt is unnecessary, but upper bolt below the anchors is nice. It has a shared 2-bolt anchor.
content.location: The North side of the Watchtower has two bolted routes currently - an 11a with a tricky start right and the 9 crack that steps left. This is the crack. Start by either scrambling up from a bushy gully or 4th Classing from a ledge on left, perhaps anchoring from the first bolt.
